prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We propose for purely continuum (correlator in TDM) observations at Band 7. The representative frequency chosen is the one which minimizes the total time, as estimated using the Sensitivity Calculator.

To spatially separate the thermal continuum emission in individual components we require an angular resolution of 0.15 arcsec. At Band 7, this resolution can be reached with any of three extended/long configurations C36-5, C36-6, and C36-7. The Largest Angular Structure we wish to image is 0.2 arcsec, thus neither additional configurations not ACA are needed. Our target fully fits within a third of the primary beam, ensuring uniform sensitivity throughout.

To study the thermal continuum emission at rest-frame wavelength of about 350 microns, we propose for ALMA observations at Band 7. Based on our spectral energy distribution decomposition method, which makes use of Spitzer and Herschel data (see Figure 1 in Scientific Justification), we estimate a total continuum flux density of roughly 1.5 mJy at this particular wavelength. Given our requested angular resolution of 0.15 arcsec (see below), and further assuming that this flux density is distributed in half a dozen discrete components each extending 0.2 arcsec, we estimate the flux density to be about 0.17 mJy per synthesized ALMA beam. Requesting a signal-to-noise ratio of 5, we set the continuum sensitivity to 35 micro Jansky.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: High-redshift, radio-loud active galactic nuclei (AGN) provide a unique opportunity to probe the interplay between actively accreting black holes and their massive host galaxies. We performed a full infrared spectral energy distribution analysis of a complete sample of z>1 3CR sources, and found star formation (SF) rates of hundreds of solar masses per year in about half of the sample hosts. We discovered a clear trend where objects with subgalactic (<30 kpc) radio sources are much more common to show intense SF. This strongly suggests the occurrence of jet-induced SF (positive feedback) in massive galaxies during the peak epoch of AGN and SF activity. We request 0.15 arcsec resolution imaging of rest-frame 350 micron dust continuum emission in the hosts of five subgalactic 3CR radio galaxies and quasars, to zoom in on the SF activity on ~1 kpc physical scale, and test the positive feedback hypothesis. The resulting images will permit spatial separation of the nuclear (<1 kpc) and the extranuclear dust emission. Moreover, overlaid on deep, sub-arcsec resolution radio images, they will permit identification and quantification of positive feedback in these landmark objects.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Code: 2013.1.01132.S Title: Zooming in on the extreme galaxy growth in distant, powerful, radio-loud AGN PI: P. Barthel

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Kapteyn Astronomical Institute, University of Groningen

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Kapteyn Astronomical Institute, University of Groningen
Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, CHANDRA X-ray Observatory
Division of Physics Mathematics and Astronomy, California Institute of Technology
